author: Karl Marx
specific_section: Chapter 1, Section 4: The Fetishism of the Commodity
plain_language_summary: Marx introduces the concept of 'commodity fetishism'—the way social relations between people appear as relations between things. This concept helps explain how market relationships can seem natural and apolitical when they're actually structured by power.

author: Antonio Gramsci
plain_language_summary: Gramsci argues that ruling classes maintain power not just through force but by winning 'cultural hegemony'—making their worldview appear natural and common sense. Media play a key role in spreading hegemonic ideas that serve elite interests.

author: Rosa Luxemburg
specific_section: Part I: The Problem of Imperialism
plain_language_summary: Luxemburg argues that capitalism cannot sustain itself through internal markets alone and must constantly expand into non-capitalist territories and populations. This framework reveals the economic imperatives behind military intervention and globalization narratives.

author: Rosa Luxemburg
plain_language_summary: Luxemburg argues that reform and revolution cannot be separated—attempts to reform capitalism within its existing framework ultimately fail because the system inherently requires exploitation. True change requires revolutionary transformation of the relations of production.

author: Rosa Luxemburg
work_title: The Mass Strike, the Political Party and the Trade Unions
plain_language_summary: Luxemburg analyzes how mass strikes arise spontaneously from workers' lived experience of exploitation rather than from party directives. Economic and political struggles are inseparable, and working-class self-activity generates its own forms of organization.

author: Karl Marx & Friedrich Engels
plain_language_summary: Marx and Engels argue that the ideas of the ruling class become the dominant ideas in any society because they control the means of material production AND the means of mental production. The ruling ideas are the ideas of ruling material relations.

author: Karl Marx
plain_language_summary: The economic base (means and relations of production) determines the superstructure (law, politics, ideology). The superstructure serves to reproduce the conditions of production.

author: Hal Draper
work_title: The Adventures of the Socialist Program
plain_language_summary: Draper distinguishes between 'socialism from above' (reforms handed down by the state) and 'socialism from below' (self-emancipation by working people). The 'lesser evil' logic traps workers in supporting parties that serve capital.

concept_name: Imperialism as Highest Stage of Capitalism
author: Vladimir Lenin
work_title: Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism
plain_language_summary: Lenin argues that imperialism is a structural stage of capitalism characterized by finance capital, monopoly, and the export of capital. Foreign policy is driven by the needs of finance capital, not diplomatic choice or national interest.

author: Vladimir Lenin
plain_language_summary: Lenin argues that in bourgeois democracy, the state is an instrument of class domination. Even formal democracy serves the ruling class because the economic base determines who can participate meaningfully in political life.

concept_name: The Woman Question as Class Question
author: Clara Zetkin
plain_language_summary: Zetkin argues that the oppression of women cannot be solved within capitalism—it is bound up with private property and the family as economic unit. Bourgeois feminism obscures the class division among women.

author: Alexandra Kollontai
work_title: The Communist Attack on the Family
plain_language_summary: Kollontai argues that bourgeois morality and the family are ideologically constructed to serve accumulation. Women's oppression is rooted in property relations, not biology or nature.

author: C. L. R. James
specific_section: Toussaint L'Ouverture and the San Domingo Revolution
plain_language_summary: James analyzes the Haitian Revolution as an example of Black self-emancipation, challenging narratives that erase the autonomous agency of oppressed peoples in historical change.

author: George Padmore
plain_language_summary: Padmore reveals how colonial administration is fundamentally about economic extraction disguised as civilizing mission. The rhetoric of development and modernization masks systematic plunder.

concept_name: Crisis Theory & Falling Rate of Profit
author: Paul Mattick
work_title: Marx and Keynes: The Limits of the Mixed Economy
plain_language_summary: Mattick argues that crises are inherent to capitalism, not caused by bad actors or poor regulation. The falling rate of profit drives periodic crises, and state intervention merely postpones rather than solves them.

author: Paul Lafargue
plain_language_summary: Lafargue argues that private property is not a natural right but a historically specific institution serving class interests. The 'right to property' is really the right of the owning class to exploit labor.

author: Antonio Gramsci
plain_language_summary: Gramsci analyzes how Fordism reshapes not just production but workers' bodies, sexuality, morality, and culture to serve capital. What appears as cultural modernization is reorganization of life around accumulation.

author: Louis Althusser
plain_language_summary: Althusser argues that schools, media, and religion function as 'Ideological State Apparatuses' that train people to accept existing social relations as natural.

author: Georgi Plekhanov
work_title: The Role of the Individual in History
plain_language_summary: Plekhanov argues that great individuals are not the primary drivers of historical change but rather express existing social forces. Their significance lies in their ability to understand and accelerate tendencies already present in society.

author: Georg Lukács
specific_section: Reification and the Consciousness of the Proletariat
plain_language_summary: Lukács develops the concept of reification—the process by which social relations appear as objective things. This extends Marx's commodity fetishism to all social phenomena under capitalism.

author: Leon Trotsky
plain_language_summary: Trotsky argues that in backward countries, the bourgeois revolution cannot be completed by the bourgeoisie itself—it can only be achieved through the revolutionary action of the proletariat and peasantry, leading directly to socialist transformation.

author: James Connolly
plain_language_summary: Connolly argues that national liberation cannot be separated from class struggle. The 'national interest' is typically the interest of the owning class, and true liberation requires challenging both foreign domination and domestic class exploitation.

author: Paul Mattick
plain_language_summary: Mattick advocates for workers' councils as the form of working-class organization that can challenge capitalist control directly, rejecting both parliamentary socialism and the bureaucratic control of trade unions.

author: Karl Marx
plain_language_summary: Marx describes how workers under capitalism are alienated from the product of their labor, the act of production, their fellow workers, and their own human potential. Work becomes a means to survival rather than self-realization.

author: Karl Marx
work_title: A Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy
plain_language_summary: Marx outlines his materialist method: the economic base (production and relations of production) determines the superstructure (legal, political, ideological forms). This is the foundation for historical materialist analysis.

author: Clara Zetkin
plain_language_summary: Zetkin analyzes fascism as a mass movement recruited from the middle classes during economic crisis, using pseudo-radical rhetoric to channel discontent away from socialism and toward scapegoats.

author: Nikolai Bukharin
plain_language_summary: Bukharin analyzes how capitalism leads to the formation of national blocs of finance capital that compete in world markets. Trade conflicts are really inter-capitalist struggles for spheres of influence.

concept_name: Origin of Family, Private Property and State
author: Friedrich Engels
work_title: The Origin of the Family, Private Property and the State
plain_language_summary: Engels argues that the family, private property, and the state all arose together as instruments of class rule. The oppression of women is bound up with the emergence of private property.

author: Hal Draper
plain_language_summary: Draper develops a theory of socialism from below—where working people themselves organize to take control of production, rejecting both state capitalism and bureaucratic union control.

author: Karl Marx
plain_language_summary: Marx and Engels argue that the history of all society is the history of class struggles. The bourgeoisie has torn apart the feudal ties and replaced them with pure money relations, creating new classes and class antagonisms.
